newsitem.title: INDIA: India aims for interest rates cuts, eyes inflation.
newsitem.headline: India aims for interest rates cuts, eyes inflation.

text.p: India's central bank loosened its credit policy on Tuesday in a bid to bring down interest rates and keep economic growth on track while containing inflation.
The central bank's measures barely registered in Indian markets, where investors remained focused on the United Front (UF) alliance's efforts to form a new government.
Caretaker Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda has agreed to step down as leader of the coalition in order to satisfy the Congress party's conditions for supporting another UF-led government.

The Reserve Bank of India's (RBI's) moves to boost commercial banks' loanable funds will complement the fallen government's stalled 1997/98 (April-March) budget plan, which will be debated in parliament next week.

"Inflation is around 7.3 percent now," RBI governor Chakravarty Rangarajan told Reuters Television. "I think we need to take inflation further down. I would be happier with a rate closer to six percent rather than seven percent." The central bank chief said slower expansion in M3 money supply in 1997/98 should help keep inflation in check.
"I think our 1997/98 monetary target of 15.0-15.5 percent (for M3 expansion) should help us reach our target of lower inflation," Rangarajan said.

The twin objective of the RBI is to contain inflationary pressures without affecting adequate bank credit to support real gross domestic product growth of 6.0-7.0 percent in 1997/98, he said in a letter to banks spelling out the RBI's credit policy.
"The projected increase in money supply may be reviewed and revised depending upon macro-economic developments," he said.
M3 grew by 15.6 percent in 1996/97 and real GDP (gross domestic product) is expected to have grown by 6.8 percent, the credit policy statement said.
Rangarajan said he expected interest rates to come down as a result of the policy, which also lowered interest rates on bank deposits.
"I think interest rates will come down, because the steps taken in this policy will lead to an increase in the lendable resources of banks," he said.
The lowest prime lending rate among India's major banks is 14.5 percent.

"We have also lowered deposit rates which should get reflected in lower lending rates," Rangarajan said. "The full impact of the reduction in cash reserve ratios made last year will be felt this year. This will also help."
The central bank reduced the ceiling on interest on deposits up to one year by one percentage point to 9.0 percent to give banks more leeway to cut lending rates.
Rangarajan said a number of steps had been taken in the credit policy to improve the credit delivery system.
"We have given greater autonomy to banks to determine working capital limits for borrowers and also eased norms on consortium lending," he said.
Rangarajan said the capital market would be boosted by credit policy announcements allowing banks to invest more in shares of companies.
The RBI also said it was removing reserve requirements on inter-bank borrowings. The move is expected to pave the way for the creation of an inter-bank term lending market.
